Posts.Content: May 4, 2009 09:30AM BrandyWK wrote: This is just my opinion & my story.  My mother was diagnosed 20 years ago when she was only 38 with Stage 4 breast cancer.  A few years ago, my sister was diagnosed with stage one breast cancer at the age of 34.  My sister did do the BRCA1 & BRCA 2 testing, but she was negative.  I am having preventative surgery in 2 days...double mastectomy with immediate reconstruction (DIEP Flap).  The oncologist (who also is my sister's doc) said that it was up to me whether I wanted to get tested or not.  But he said that regardless, because of such strong family history, I could be negative, but still be at high risk.  The testing isn't cheap.  And seeing how my risk is still high, I opted not to have the testing done.  Good luck in whatever you do!

Posts.Content: May 4, 2009 02:23PM BrandyWK wrote: I am having prophylactic surgery (bilateral mastectomy with DIEP reconstruction) in 2 days.  My mother had stage 4 breast cancer when she was 38.  My sister was diagnosed with breast cancer 2 years ago at the ripe old age of 34.  I'm 33, will be 34 this year.  Both my younger sister & I have to get mammo's every year.  My sister who had the cancer took the BRCA test & was found NEGATIVE.  So, with me, the oncologist said it was up to me whether I wanted to be tested or not, but that even it was negative, it would NOT reduce my high risk.  Obviously, there is something going on in our family.  The docs don't know every strand of cancer that there is.  The BRCA tests only test for what they do know.  Not only that, it's not a cheap test.  If you have a strong family history, that is proof enough of your risk, even without the testing.  I have been thinking about prophylactic surgery for the past 2 years.  I didn't think my insurance would pay for it.  But, with the wonderful help of my plastic surgeon's office, my insurance agreed to pay.  Of course, there is some out of pocket expense, but it's not that bad.  And I do agree with having MRI's.  I had one last week as part of testing before my big surgery and it showed some "abnormalities" in both breasts (although more in my left) even though I just had a mammo in October of last year.  MRI's show more than mammo's.  So now, given the findings, the oncologist will do a sentinal node biopsy while doing the mastectomy on both breasts & will get results almost immediately, during surgery.  If positive (cancerous) he'll remove more lymph nodes.  If not, he'll let the plastic surgeon take over.  Of course, this is major surgery & I'd be a fool to say that I'm not anxious & nervous.  But I'm not doubting my decision one bit.  I won't have that "what if they find it this time" every year that I go in for my mammo.  Good luck all!

Posts.Content: May 4, 2009 12:32PM BrandyWK wrote: This is such a heart-wrenching, devasting thing for women.  I'm 33 & am having prophylactic mastectomy with DIEP Flap reconstruction in 2 days.  And I can tell you, both the oncologist & plastic surgeon that I am seeing work as a team and spent no less than 2 hours with me going over everything.  This is how it should be.  Go with your gut.  I say it's time for a second opinion.  I think there should be no fooling around when it comes to your health, especially cancer.  I wish you all the luck in the world!
